content.description: Vertical Smile is A great project if you need something in the low 12's that is not all juggy at chuck, it starts out with some bouldery moves, which leads to a possible ground fall at the third bolt and then passes some crimpy/slopey face climbing up to a nice bulge and a really reachy move just before the 6th bolt and then goes right to join pilgrimage on a shared bolt and anchors. Awesome climb!!
content.location: Just outside of the slot. Just to the right of Mecca and to the left of Pilgrimage.

content.description: This route is to the left of Dirtbag (there's a route between Dirtbag and this one).  Nice pockets lead to nice ledges and more pockets.  A bulge at the end is conquered by some reachy holds.
content.protection: 7 draws should be plenty for bolts and anchors

content.description: The hardest route at Chuckawalla, this fun climb starts with some hard slot climbing with bad feet (5.12) with a big right hand throw to a hidden pocket.  Do a little hand negotiation and funky moves to gain a good rail up and left, clip, and fire through the marginal pockets, with terrible feet, and throw a heel up and right to gain a big jug hole(V7).  The climbing backs off significantly, and is alot of fun moving between the big pods to gain anchors over the lip.
content.protection: 6 bolts, some better placed than others, to chains over the lip.
content.location: on the far left end of the cave, this is the second route to the right, which branches up and left from a common start.

content.description: 2 routes to the left of Second Coming.  Just above 2nd bolt gaston with R hand, then up high with L.  From 5th to 6th bolt, reachy move with R hand to huge undercling.  Good rest just below 5th bolt.

One route left of 3 Bars Black, this route is short and powerful with good crimps and shallow pockets. Big dyno right off the ground followed by a hard cross and thin edges. A great boulder problem... I mean route. A good first 13a for you boulders out there.
content.protection: This route is 4 bolts and a 2-bolt chain anchor, and I suggest using a stick clip if you have one.
content.location: This route is just to the left of 3 bars black and is the farthest left route on Chuckawalla.

content.description:
This route is sandwiched between

Dirtbag

and

Apostasy

.  It's a bit similar to both.  Big, juggy holds up to the last bolt.  The finish is committing on some crimpy stuff.  Fun route.

According to the Goss Guide this is one of two 3-star climbs at

Chuckawalla Wall

, and, according to a Nov '03 Climbing magazine article, this climb is supposedly the 'premiere route on the wall.'

These are at best a measured compliment and at worst a back-handed insult to the remaining climbs in the area. While it is a *good* route, there is nothing particularly classic about it. Then again, this wall is a summer morning or winter afternoon playground, not a roadtrip destination.

A slightly powerful move down low (upper body strength dependent) gets you off of the ground past the first clip (10b?) from where you can proceed past 5.10 climbing to the crux near the 3rd clip, moving left to a not-so-good hold. (12a) Then finishing on easier but pumpy climbing (5.11?) to the arete and beyond for a total of 20 meters to the chains up top.

Hard to on-sight, less difficult to red point once you know what to expect of the crux holds and go for it instead of messing around to find the best ones.
content.location:
This route is the 8th from the right on the wall.

Rather than counting bolt lines, find the climb by locating the hanging right-facing dihedral up high on the wall, just right of center. Spot the chalked line on the arete to its left side and follow the line to the ground. That is the line of this climb.

content.description: One hard move off small crimp at first or second bolt leads to easier climbing above.
content.location: Just left of Captain Rehab, right of As The Jerks Fly.

content.description: The first line on the right.  It starts fun, but eases up past the ledge to the chains.
content.protection: All bolts 4?  I think, plus chains.

climbs.name: Sands of Anarchy
climbs.fa: Gordon Larsen, Hyrum Colier, Marty Larsen

content.description: Short, bouldery pocketed line to the right of Sand Puppy.
content.location: Right of Sand Puppy and left of Sand Castle.

content.description: New route on the far north of the crag in the shaded slot.  Right of Sand Puppy.  Sandy rock leads to better holds up top with the crux just before the chain anchors.  Not the best route at the crag, but another quick option for climbing in the shade of the narrow slot.
Reachy crimpers and a good rest lead to fun thin topout. Crux is the top and after the second bolt with very thin pinchers. A hard 11b and a worthwhile journey.
content.location: It has been noted: This is clearly two routes to the right of the easy to spot low anchors of Armageddon. It is the first 5.11 on the wall moving from the right to the left after all of the 5.10 routes. The pic shows the route.

content.description: This is a short route on your left when you walk up into the corridor towards the 13's on the far left of Chuckwalla.  It is short and a bit sandy.  Steep start to slab middle and pod.
content.protection: 4 Bolts to nice Fixe chain anchors

content.description:
This climb is the fifth from the right on the wall, past a route on the junky-looking blunt arete and the climbs

Apostasy

, and unknown 5.10, and

Dirtbag

.

Descend 150 meters from the parking lot to the wall and walk to a line of bolts perhaps 9 meters left or the right-hand edge of the main buttress.  Although the line is somewhat squeezed between Dirtbag and Tombstone Bullets, which preceded it by some years, the climbing is reasonably good. You just have to ignore the bolts and holds on T.B. which you could nearly clip.

A slightly powerful crux gets you off of the ground (10a?) and moving up easier climbing for 7 meters to a more blank area of the wall. This crux (10c) can be avoided by stepping left or right to one of the routes it is squeezed between if you like. Then the climb ascends to a final crux near the top (10a), just before the chain anchors. The line has 5 or 6 bolts leading to chains up top. I found this route just a little more difficult than Dirtbag (10a).
content.protection: A rack of draws, plus something up top for the chain anchor.

content.description:
This fun line start off hard with a low crux past the second bolt and then eases to steep climbing on good holds - if you nail the crux it's all about hanging on for the ride.

Don't be confused by another line of bolts that branch off after the 2nd bolt, as they belong to another route -

As the Jerks Fly

(5.12a).
content.location: Center of the wall between Vertical Smile on the left and Say your Prayers.

content.description: Route just to the right of As the Crows Fly (the anchors are within arm's reach of each other).  Starts out with nice pockets to a slopey, reachy crux.  After the third bolt, it's big holds to the chains.  There's a bit of a left traverse at the end.

climbs.name: Just Another Bolt in the Wall

content.description: just to the right of good luck chuck.  Clip the second bolt then head up on good edges and pockets to a spicy mantle.  Hit the Huecos and then head for the chains up top.  The first bolt can be skipped as it's close to the second however this would make the clip extra spicy.  The ending is fabulous!

While I don't personally know Chuck, after climbing this line I imagine him a pleasant man, well-mannered, strong and stoic. When irritated, Chuck can get upset and difficult to deal with, but given some time to cool down, he'll regain his composure and shrug things off.

A short and powerful route,

Good Old Chuck

starts off casual and leads to a deceptive, devious, and explosive crux. Unravel the boulderesque bulge or peril!! Allow the dust to clear, pull past the tornado, and climb towards safer ground.

*Game shoes required.

Begin this route on big pockets and deep edges, gain a stance and let the fun begin. Balance, question, and second guess your next few moves through the bulge and if you're lucky, passage will be granted. Finish out the route on steepening terrain using side pulls and scoops.
content.location:
This is the third and shortest line in from the far left wall.

Good Old Chuck

is directly left of

Garden of Eden

content.description:
This route is best found by walking to the left end of the buttress and then back-tracking to the right 2 lines. The climb can be identified by the features on and around it. On the ground, a swell of rock to the left goes up a little slot to access the ledge before the climb's first bolt. The climb ascends past a bolt below a bulge, over the bulge for a clip that will be either tricky or high-ball (crux, height dependent 10c). Note closing comments on this. Past the second clip the climbing eases slightly to bigger holds and shorter moves (5.9?) on a left-leaning line to reach chain anchors.

Both the belayer and climber should consider this second clip carefully, as the clip is tricky and insecure from down low and a little highball from past the crux. With the ledge below, blowing the clip could be an ankle-breaker.As well, the previous bolt is long enough that one is tempted to clip it with a longer sling to avoid drag later, but this will lengthen a fall. I caught my partner on 3 lead falls from the crux, each ending perhaps a foot above the ledge.  If I'd not paid close attention or if she'd outweighed me, she might have hit it hard.
content.protection: A rack of draws, including one longer sling plus something up top for the chain anchor.

content.description:
Bolted route just to the the right of

Second Coming

. A bouldery start leads to easier climbing and a great rest.  Climb the arete and clip the chains.
content.location:
Middle of the wall, just right of

Second Coming

.

content.description: This route is a bit more techy for the first half than most of the harder routes on the wall.    Climb up and work your way a bit left using small slots for your fingers.   Clip the 2nd bolt, gain a few crimps and make a lunge for a jug up and right.   Clip the 3rd bolt, and use a few small but positive pockets to gain a stance.  Its cruiser from here.    At the 3rd bolt, you can bust left to do Three Bars Black, 5.13b.
content.location: This is the 2nd route from the far left side of the wall.

content.description:
Double Cross

begins tough and ends tough. A very difficult start on pockets and thin crimps leads through a bulge and a hard to manage second clip, continue up and slightly left on more crimps and an occasional pocket. Work right along a shallow ledge and aim up and right into a small recess and shared chain anchor.
content.location:
Double Cross

is right of

Garden of Eden

and left of

The Cross

.

Double Cross

is the fifth route in from the far left of the wall.

content.description:
This climb is the fourth from the right on the wall, past

Sands of Blood

on the junky-looking blunt arete,

Apostasy

, and

Solace

.

Descend 150 meters from the parking lot to the wall and walk to a line of bolts perhaps 7 meters left or the right-hand edge of the main buttress. A line of 4 bolts leads to chains up top.

The climbing is mostly positive, but a crux up top is a little awkward and thin, so it might not be the best warm up, particularly for shorter climbers. I found this route just a little more difficult than its 5.10a neighbor.
content.protection: 7 bolts up to a 2 bolt anchor.

content.description:
The Cross

is a hard and relentless route with a bouldery crux about a little over half way up, pull this move, follow the thin crack, and save your strength for the surprise ending.
content.protection: Five draws + anchors (slings are nice for the top)
content.location:
The Cross

is the sixth route in from the far left wall. Its most recognized by a thin, vertical, crack that runs up and stops just prior to the top.

The Cross

is just left of

As The Crow Flies

content.description: This is a cool climb, and more solid for the grade compared to some of the other 12a's at this wall.   Start by climbing Pilgrimage, 5.12a to the second bolt.  Don't clip the second bolt on Pilgrimage and continue up the dihedral to the right.   Clipping the bolt near the top of the dihedral begins As the Jerks Fly.   From here, it's straight up on some marginal holds (crux).   Continue straight up gaining a few pods and finger locks in a vertical crack.   Increasingly better holds lead to the chains.  The second bolt is a bit high, you can clip the 2nd bolt on Pilgrimage with a long runner, or unclip your draw when you reach the first bolt on As the Jerks Fly.
content.location: Start by climbing Pilgrimage, below of shallow right facing dihedral.

content.description: A fun pocket route on the far left of the wall.  Follow pockets and edges to a crux near the top.  Find the hidden pocket at the second to last clip,  and crank to the anchors.  6 bolts...
Chossy holds up seam past five bolts to chains
content.location: In-between Sand-witch and farmers tan (according to the climbing guide it would be between Sand-witch and second coming)

content.description:
This is nearly the right-most climb on the wall, with the exception of a junky-looking blunt arete.  Descend 150 meters from the parking lot to the wall and walk to a line of bolts perhaps 4 meters left of the right-hand edge of the main buttress.  A line of 5 bolts leads to chains up top.

The climbing is mostly positive and is a reasonable warm up, although I found this route just a little more slick than its immediate neighbors.
content.protection: A rack of draws, plus something up top for the chain anchor.

content.description: Crux down low through a bulge with poor pockets.  Second crux up at the top where the route turns into a slab.
content.location: Immediately to the right of Armageddon
